description: This module is a sociological and anthropological study of the neoliberal transformations of work that has been shaped by global financial crises in recent decades, which have in turn led to suggest changes to employment choices and work patterns. Examining the opportunities and challenges that affect how individuals could, would, and actually work would enable students to better understand and manage diverse aspects of career demands, educational pursuits, family life, social relations, employment, cultural heritage, leisure and public services in todayâ€™s rapidly changing global economy.
title: Social Origins and Consequences of Financial Crises
